22023.name: Striped Cast Sock
22023.sizes_available: Fits a cast about 11" in circumference
22023.notes_html:
This special, super-soft ribbed ‘sock’ keeps your toes cozy if you have to wear a cast on a broken leg or ankle! Elastic thread is used to give the cover a strong grip so it stays on.

Lion Brand Pattern #: BK4K-20060101
kcashmere-toeSock.pdf

Approximately 8” in circumference x 7” long
(11.5 x 132 cm) with ribbing relaxed.
Fits a cast about 11” in circumference comfortably.

Lion Brand Cashmere Blend
84yrds/71m (1.5oz/40g)
270-153 Black - 1 skein
270-113 Red - 1 skein

Knitting Needles - Size 8 (5 mm}

Gauge: 26 stitches = 4” / 10cm in pattern stitch

Approximately 3 yds (3 m) elastic thread

pattern_author.name: Joan L. Hamer
pattern_author.notes: I’ve been knitting forever and published a 12-page quarterly called Pine Meadow Knitting News for 11 years until about 5 years ago. I am retired from The Mannings, a huge and wonderful yarn shop and teaching studio. I teach classes at Knitter’s Day Out, our local library and guild and anyone who wants me within a 100 miles radius. I have lots of patterns in my Ravelry shop.

44546.name: Inhaler Sock to the Rescue!
44546.notes_html:
This is a sock like cozy for any type of inhaler. This particular one was made for my Albuterol rescue inhaler as a way to make sure my inhaler stays clean and dry while living in my purse or pocket.

It can be adjusted to fit any size inhaler, just add more rows to make it longer or shorter, add or subtract stitches to cast on to make it bigger or smaller.

This is instant gratification and depending on your speed, will only take just over an hour to knit from start to finish.

users.about_me:
I turned sixty-one this year, retired from the local public library in 2015 and still married to a guy who can make me laugh...sometimes with him, often *at* him! 

I crochet a lot faster than I knit and usually have a movie on at the same time. I'm seldom without a book handy and I tend to binge-read whenever I find a new author that I like. 

All the *kids* are over 21. Justin (our oldest) has given us five grandkids and Zachary has given us two! LOL

80882.name: "Hey, at Least It Wasn't Your Leg" Arm Sling
80882.gauge_description: 16 stitches and 20 rows = 4 inches in Stockinette stitch
80882.notes_html:
Pattern description from Knockdown Knits: “The second any girl joins roller derby, she starts hearing one thing over and over. ‘You’re going to break your leg!’ So all you gals with broken arms, dislocated shoulders, or snapped wrists just go ahead and gloat at those people that try to say, ‘I told you so!’ Because they were wrong, you didn’t break your leg after all! In all seriousness, dislocated shoulders seem to be a pretty common derby injury. And those slings you see at the drugstore have no style for a derby girl at all! So knit this sling up in your favorite color or in your team colors! It’s cute, soft, and comfy and slips easily into a pocket on your skate bag - just in case you need it after a bout!”

Skill Level: Rookie

Materials:

  • Plymouth Yarn Encore Worsted (75% acrylic, 25% wool, 200 yd. 183m per 3.5 oz. 100g skein); 1 skein #670 Teal Heather
  • US 8 5mm straight needles
  • Tapestry needle
  • 1.25 inch plastic strap adjuster (sold at craft stores), such as used for a backpack
  • 0.5 yard fabric for lining (optional)
  • Matching sewing thread and needle for lining (optional)

Finished Measurements:

  • Length: 15”
  • Circumference: 13”
80882.notes:
**Pattern description from *Knockdown Knits*:** "The second any girl joins roller derby, she starts hearing one thing over and over.  'You're going to break your leg!'  So all you gals with broken arms, dislocated shoulders, or snapped wrists just go ahead and gloat at those people that try to say, 'I told you so!'  Because they were wrong, you didn't break your leg after all!  In all seriousness, dislocated shoulders seem to be a pretty common derby injury.  And those slings you see at the drugstore have no style  for a derby girl at all!  So knit this sling up in your favorite color or in your team colors!  It's cute, soft, and comfy and slips easily into a pocket on your skate bag - just in case you need it after a bout!"

**Skill Level:** Rookie

**Materials:**

* Plymouth Yarn *Encore Worsted* (75% acrylic, 25% wool, 200 yd. [183m] per 3.5 oz. [100g] skein); 1 skein #670 Teal Heather
* US 8 [5mm] straight needles
* Tapestry needle
* 1.25 inch plastic strap adjuster (sold at craft stores), such as used for a backpack
* 0.5 yard fabric for lining (optional)
* Matching sewing thread and needle for lining (optional)

**Finished Measurements:**

* Length: 15"
* Circumference: 13"

80981.name: Arm Sling
80981.gauge_description: 18 stitches and 24 rows = 4 inches in Stockinette stitch
80981.notes_html:
Pattern description from Knockdown Knits: “Broken bones are just a part of derby. The chances of a girl in your league breaking something are huge! Tailbones, arms, legs, ankles; it’s just going to happen. Unlike ‘normal people,’ however, derby girls relish their gross X-rays, surgery pictures, and gnarly injuries. Broken Arm Sweater is a great way to show off your downright pride of those snapped bones. Even though the instruction but the broken bone on the lower arm, feel free to use the chart of the upper arm, ribs, back, or wherever you want it. It’s a simple sweater and easy to alter. If you feel up to the challenge, tackle the bonus in this pattern and turn your sweater into an actual working sling! The felted straps and buckles give it a neat bondage look, and it will actually be practical for those bad days when past snaps and sprains come back to haunt you and your poor arm/shoulder/wrist jut needs a little relief.”

Skill Level: Vet

Materials:

  • Cascade 220: 1 skein #7803 Magenta (CC2)
  • Sewing needle and thread to match CC2
  • 1” buckles (2)

This pattern may be found in the Bonus Section for the Broken Arm Sweater on pages 32-34.
80981.notes:

Tailbones, arms, legs, ankles; it’s just going to happen. Unlike ‘normal people,’ however, derby girls relish their gross X-rays, surgery pictures, and gnarly injuries. [Broken Arm Sweater][1] is a great way to show off your downright pride of those snapped bones. Even though the instruction but the broken bone on the lower arm, feel free to use the chart of the upper arm, ribs, back, or wherever you want it. It’s a simple sweater and easy to alter. If you feel up to the challenge, tackle the bonus in this pattern and turn your sweater into an actual working sling! The felted straps and buckles give it a neat bondage look, and it will actually be practical for those bad days when past snaps and sprains come back to haunt you and your poor arm/shoulder/wrist jut needs a little relief.”

Skill Level: Vet

**Materials:**

* Cascade 220: 1 skein #7803 Magenta (CC2)
* Sewing needle and thread to match CC2
* 1” buckles (2)

This pattern may be found in the Bonus Section for the [Broken Arm Sweater][2] on pages 32-34.


  [1]: http://www.ravelry.com/patterns/library/broken-arm-sweater
  [2]: http://www.ravelry.com/patterns/library/broken-arm-sweater

users.about_me: I own a coffee shop, I firmly believe that kindness matters, I work way too many hours, and possibly have way too many animals. Author of 3 knitting books, Knockdown Knits, Knits for Nerds and Geek Knits. I have one baby girl that is the result of YEARS of infertility treatments, which I'm an open book about.  My website, twitter, and facebook make me easy to find and say "hi!" If you follow me on twitter, be warned my alter ego is Joan of Drunk, and she rambles a lot.

113200.name: Toe Cosy
113200.notes_html:
I had to have bunion surgery, and it’s been one of the coldest Februarys in NC in awhile! The surgical shoe I was given for recovery does not keep my poor little bruised tootsies covered, so what’s a knitter to do? Make a toe cosy, of course! While this is written for a rather large size, it should be easily scalable. I used the gauge listed on the ball band, measured the width of my boot’s toe (4”) and off I went without swatching. If making this for someone else, making a larger size should still work, as the attached ankle strap keeps the cosy secure even if it’s too big, and the strap can be adjusted with safety pins to customize the fit.

If you’ve got to have the surgery, you might as well have some festive yarn to keep you happy! Enjoy!
113200.notes:
I had to have bunion surgery, and it's been one of the coldest Februarys in NC in awhile!  The surgical shoe I was given for recovery does not keep my poor little bruised tootsies covered, so what's a knitter to do?  Make a toe cosy, of course!  While this is written for a rather large size, it should be easily scalable.  I used the gauge listed on the ball band, measured the width of my boot's toe (4") and off I went without swatching.  If making this for someone else, making a larger size should still work, as the attached ankle strap keeps the cosy secure even if it's too big, and the strap can be adjusted with safety pins to customize the fit.

If you've got to have the surgery, you might as well have some festive yarn to keep you happy!  Enjoy!

Analytical chemist.  Prefer knitting.  Hate designing (hate is fading, more like blind terror combined with peak'd interest).  More projects than time.  Crazy daughter likes my socks and is allowed 2 pair a year, husband won't wear wool (but likes cables).

Update: Have put my first pattern here on Ravelry (yeah!), and husband is now giving me knitting requests.  Kid still likes socks.

125592.name: Cast Cozy
125592.notes_html:
This is a toe cover for people in leg casts. The pattern uses a dense slipped-stitch rib to really cling to the cast and to the toes. It’ll keep you warm!

I used Louet Gems because I had it around, but any worsted yarn would do. This is an easily customizable pattern, and it’s a great way to burn up partial balls of yarn.

I’m not just the designer of this pattern, I’m also a wearer.

211104.name: CPAP Hose Cozy
211104.sizes_available: Custom, can be adjusted for 6' and 8' hoses, Can also be used for short mask-hose
211104.gauge_description: 3 stitches and 3.75 rows = 1 inch in Stockinette Stitch
211104.notes_html:
I’m making a new one, current model is due for retirement! LOL Will add photos as I get through the steps.

For winter “Rain-out” or condensation issues. I also like to keep my humidity high, so hose covers are a god-send! But i can make thicker, more durable covers with inexpensive thread than buying a thin fleece cover and paying for shipping!

This is a super fast-knit project that can add a personal touch for a CPAP user you love (including yourself). Start simple and you find that getting fancier is fun!

Take some time to make a sample, 1” or 2” to try on the hose in order to get your gage and style correct. These instructions are for felting though you may, for ease, choose to leave it knit-plain (St-stitch), try using a ribbing pattern to get a more snug but flexible fit, or mix it up with a stitch you find in a dictionary!

Again, I like to felt this project, so I suggested my favorite felting yarn and I recommend knitting loosely and longer than you need to account for shrinkage in the felting process. You may also want to try larger needles if it still comes out too tight. You may also add a few stitches if your tension is naturally tighter.

Tight results are not terrible - Try sliding a plastic bag over the rubber connector on the end of the CPAP hose - this always helps getting your cozy onto the hose!
211104.notes:
I'm making a new one, current model is due for retirement!  LOL  Will add photos as I get through the steps.

For winter "Rain-out" or condensation issues.  I also like to keep my humidity high, so hose covers are a god-send!  But i can make thicker, more durable covers with inexpensive thread than buying a thin fleece cover and paying for shipping!

This is a super fast-knit project that can add a personal touch for a CPAP user you love (including yourself). Start simple and you find that getting fancier is fun!

Take some time to make a sample, 1" or 2" to try on the hose in order to get your gage and style correct.   These instructions are for felting though you may, for ease, choose to leave it knit-plain (St-stitch), try using a ribbing pattern to get a more snug but flexible fit, or mix it up with a stitch you find in a dictionary!

Again, I like to felt this project, so I suggested my favorite felting yarn and I recommend knitting loosely and longer than you need to account for shrinkage in the felting process.  You may also want to try larger needles if it still comes out too tight. You may also add a few stitches if your tension is naturally tighter.

Tight results are not terrible - Try sliding a plastic bag over the rubber connector on the end of the CPAP hose - this **always** helps getting your cozy onto the hose!

221824.name: Sock Hat (Toe Warmer)
221824.notes_html:
My friend had her ankle in a cast for a while, and asked me to knit something to keep her toes warm. She wanted sock yarn so she wouldn’t get too warm, and she wanted it to tuck down inside the cast.

NOTE: Tucking it down inside the cast didn’t work very well, it wouldn’t stay on when she got up and walked around. I ended up making it several inches longer and she wore it OVER the cast, which worked much better. The pattern was updated for the longer size on 2/9/11 (picture hasn’t been updated yet).
221824.notes:
My friend had her ankle in a cast for a while, and asked me to knit something to keep her toes warm. She wanted sock yarn so she wouldn't get too warm, and she wanted it to tuck down inside the cast. 

***NOTE: Tucking it down inside the cast didn't work very well, it wouldn't stay on when she got up and walked around. I ended up making it several inches longer and she wore it OVER the cast, which worked much better. The pattern was updated for the longer size on 2/9/11 (picture hasn't been updated yet).***

I'm fortunate to live in [Harrisonburg, Virginia][1], part of the beautiful [Shenandoah Valley][2]. To subsidize my yarn habit, I'm an **Accountant/Benefits Manager** at a construction company.

Besides knitting whenever possible (mostly socks), I like to:

- Crochet
- Solve [cryptic crosswords][3] (or regular crosswords)
- Solve Sudokus
- Read (mostly light fiction or mysteries)
- Play piano
- Catch up on my TiVo recordings (bonus - can be done while also knitting!)

298744.name: Toe Cozy Cast Cover
298744.notes_html: I injured my ankle recently and had to wear a cast. I found my uncovered toes were always cold and I needed a something to keep them cozy. I didn’t want my toe cover to fall off, so I added an ankle strap that is fastened on with a button. I hope this gives you some ideas if you find yourself or a loved one in a similar unfortunate position.
298744.notes: I injured my ankle recently and had to wear a cast. I found my uncovered toes were always cold and I needed a something to keep them cozy. I didn't want my toe cover to fall off, so I added an ankle strap that is fastened on with a button. I hope this gives you some ideas if you find yourself or a loved one in a similar unfortunate position.

363108.name: Cast Sock
363108.notes_html:
A sock to keep toes warm when a foot is in a cast. The sock is designed with an eyelet round and a drawstring in order to keep the sock on. Once the drawstring is tied, the cuff is folded over to cover the bow. Another option to keep the sock on would be to use slipper bottom non-slip paint on the inside of the body of the sock. In this case, the sock could be made shorter, leaving off the fold over cuff. If you really love knitting ribbing, the sock is stretchy enough to go over a cast, so you could also just keep right on knitting to the desired length & the sock could be pulled over the cast past the heel (think tube sock).

This pattern is pithy & written for an experienced toe up sock knitter (just one pair of socks counts!). Fits average adult man’s foot. For a smaller foot, I suggest the following changes; CO 10 sts each needle, increase every round until 26 sts (52 sts total), then inc every other round to 30 sts (60 sts total)

I knit this sock for a friend who lives out of state. I will post pics of the sock on a casted foot as soon as my friend provides them. :)

This pattern is pithy & written for an experienced toe up sock knitter (just one pair of socks counts!). Fits average adult man’s foot. For a smaller foot, I suggest the following changes; CO 10 sts each needle, increase every round until 26 sts (52 sts total), then inc every other round to 30 sts (60 sts total)

**I knit this sock for a friend who lives out of state. I will post pics of the sock on a casted foot as soon as my friend provides them. :)

pattern_author.name: Amber Perry
pattern_author.notes:
Homeschooling, married, mother of 5 beautiful children. Knitting, crocheting, and sewing keep me sane in our full house. 

You can find tutorials, free patterns, tips & tricks on my blog at [www.AmberPerryPatterns.com][1].

417716.name: Crocheted Cast-Cover Cuff for a dog
417716.notes_html:
When my dog had surgery, the cast needed to be covered and kept dry whenever she went outside. The vet gave me an IV bag and used tape to hold it in place. Kaylee has long legs, and the iv bag barely made it to the top of the cast. I crocheted a cuff attached to the bag, and included eyelets for a tie.
I’m not an experienced crocheter, so this is more of a recipe rather than a real pattern. Hopefully this will give you a start so you can make your own version of the cuff.
The cuff I made measures 3” from the top of the bag to the top of the cuff. The whole contraption measures 12 ½” from the floor to the top of the cuff. Good luck, and best wishes for your dog’s speedy recovery.

I’m not an experienced crocheter, so this is more of a recipe rather than a real pattern. Hopefully this will give you a start so you can make your own version of the cuff.
 The cuff I made measures 3” from the top of the bag to the top of the cuff. The whole contraption measures 12 ½” from the floor to the top of the cuff. Good luck, and best wishes for your dog’s speedy recovery.

444034.name: Cast Toe Warmer
444034.notes_html:
This pattern is a Free Download.

A cast on a leg or foot often means cold toes. This toe warmer is put over the end of the cast to keep those toes warm. I make lots of them for an orthopaedic office and their patients love to use them.

This is a basic, knit in the round item - much like a very small hat. It is also ideal for using up small bits of yarn in a stripe pattern.

PM me if you have any questions - I’m sa3p here on Ravelry.

It is also ideal for using up small bits of yarn in a stripe pattern. PM me if you have any questions - I'm sa3p here on Ravelry. 452810.name: Inhaler Cover
452810.notes_html: This pattern was an idea I had after I kept having to root in my bag for the inhaler. It makes my inhaler look a bit better and hooks onto my bag so is always within reach.

users.about_me:
I graduated from a textile degree from Huddersfield university back in 2018 where amongst many things I specialised in knitting.
I love all things wool related, but am most at home with my DPNs and a good doll pattern.

Favourites yarns are Hayfields Bonus DK and King Cole's merino DK... oh, and my own hand dyed skin tone wools for dolls.

I also love working on my knitting machines and use Designaknit 9.

When not drowning in wool I am found designing textile patterns and running a little quilting project called quilts of hope.

More information is on the website www.bettyvirago.com

460143.name: Swift FX Strap Cover
460143.notes_html: Personalize your ResMed Swift FX headgear. These covers are custom fit to the Swift FX headgear for CPAP therapy. They fit snuggly on the straps so they don’t move as you sleep. Wake with very mild or maybe even no strap marks.
460143.notes: Personalize your ResMed Swift FX headgear.  These covers are custom fit to the Swift FX headgear for CPAP therapy.  They fit snuggly on the straps so they don't move as you sleep.  Wake with very mild or maybe even no strap marks.

pattern_author.name: Tera Johnson
pattern_author.notes: I have been knitting on and off most of my life, but have been actively knitting for the last 4 years.  I am just now trying my hand at designing a little.  I hope you enjoy my patterns.

users.about_me:
I learned to knit when I was a young girl.  I think my first knitting was with a knitting spool made by my great aunt.  It was a continuous string of knitting that never ended.  I found that spool with the yarn still on it just a few years ago at my parents' house.  My next knitting was with a Magic Knitter from the 70's.  It was a great toy for me to play with and I was able to make little clothes for my dolls.   

As I grew toward adulthood, I began knitting out of necessity.  I was in college in upstate New York and it was cold.  Money was tight and it was cost effective to knit my own sweaters and blankets.  

After college, I joined the working world, moved south, got married, had kids...you know the routine.  Knitting wasn't a priority in life.  I did little projects like mittens, hats and dish clothes.  

In 2003 my husband gave me an EZKnitter for Christmas.  It is a version of the Ultimate Sweater Machine.  This brought me back to my love of knitting.  With that I was able make baby blankets, full size blankets, hats, sweaters...in no time flat.  It is great when you need to do quick stockinette knitting and is what prompted me to learn how to crochet.  I taught myself to crochet through books and can now make simple projects and do finished edges on knitting machine blankets.

I have now returned to hand knitting.  I love making sweaters, hats, mittens, and now socks.   I am now seen knitting in public quite often...at the park, at school, at my son's roller hockey games, at the pool.  I heard of Ravelry on the many podcasts I have begun listening to.  I am always looking for new inspiration and techniques.

At the end of April 2010, I began handspinning.  I started with a drop spindle and got a spinning wheel at the end of August 2010.  I have had a wonderful time learning about fiber and am thrilled to spin then knit my own yarn.  

I am handmadebytera on [Knitting Paradise][1] and teammom on [Craftsy][2]


  [1]: http://www.knittingparadise.com/
  [2]: http://www.craftsy.com

I learned to knit when I was a young girl. I think my first knitting was with a knitting spool made by my great aunt. It was a continuous string of knitting that never ended. I found that spool with the yarn still on it just a few years ago at my parents’ house. My next knitting was with a Magic Knitter from the 70’s. It was a great toy for me to play with and I was able to make little clothes for my dolls.

As I grew toward adulthood, I began knitting out of necessity. I was in college in upstate New York and it was cold. Money was tight and it was cost effective to knit my own sweaters and blankets.

After college, I joined the working world, moved south, got married, had kids…you know the routine. Knitting wasn’t a priority in life. I did little projects like mittens, hats and dish clothes.

In 2003 my husband gave me an EZKnitter for Christmas. It is a version of the Ultimate Sweater Machine. This brought me back to my love of knitting. With that I was able make baby blankets, full size blankets, hats, sweaters…in no time flat. It is great when you need to do quick stockinette knitting and is what prompted me to learn how to crochet. I taught myself to crochet through books and can now make simple projects and do finished edges on knitting machine blankets.

I have now returned to hand knitting. I love making sweaters, hats, mittens, and now socks. I am now seen knitting in public quite often…at the park, at school, at my son’s roller hockey games, at the pool. I heard of Ravelry on the many podcasts I have begun listening to. I am always looking for new inspiration and techniques.

At the end of April 2010, I began handspinning. I started with a drop spindle and got a spinning wheel at the end of August 2010. I have had a wonderful time learning about fiber and am thrilled to spin then knit my own yarn.

I am handmadebytera on Knitting Paradise and teammom on Craftsy

467428.name: Insulin Pump Pouch
467428.notes_html:
This pattern is for an Insulin Pump Pouch. This pattern does not include gauge as it was not necessary. It was written to fit my own Paradigm Pump by Medtronics, I am unsure of other pump brands or how this will fit any other than the Paradigm. My pump is approximately 4 1/4 inches long,1 in deep and 2 in wide. If the pump you are making a pouch for is larger then simply add more chain stitches at the beginning to add length or add more rows to add width. This is a very straight forward design for beginners to seasoned crocheters.

I used a small amount of Red Heart Super Saver in BonBon Print.

This pattern is great for using small amounts of scrap yarn.
You will also need a button, mine is 3/4 in. A small amount of sewing thread to attach the button and a yarn needle for sewing pieces together and weaving in ends.

1022595.name: Mask Mates Ear Savers
1022595.gauge_description: 7 stitches and 8 rows = 2 inches in sc
1022595.notes_html:
Video Tutorial of pattern can be found: https://youtu.be/avH5boePAYY

Wearing a mask isn’t fun to begin with but wearing it all day multiple days in a row can quickly create a lot of pain from rubbing on ears. These mask mates provide an alternative to attach the mask to behind the head, saving the ears of our frontline workers!

SIZE:
When finished, measures about 5 inches. This may vary based on gauge, but notes on how to adjust as needed.

SUPPLIES NEEDED:
-Small amount worsted weight yarn in color of choice
-(2) large buttons – 3/4 inch to 1 inch works best, below ½ inch may not hold mask
-Size H/5.00 hook
-Embroidery or Yarn Needle, Scissors

STITCHES/TECHNIQUES USED:
Pattern is in U.S. terms. Chain, half double crochet, single crochet, slip stitch.

EXPERIENCE LEVEL and TIME:
This pattern is super easy, even for beginners, and works up fast too! You can make multiple in just an hour after you get the hang of it!

If you have questions, let me know! :)
